Billy Peltzer.Action: Politely informs Mrs. Deagle that her check hasn't cleared despite her insistence and loud protest.
Refuses to cash the check of a long-time customer, maintaining bank policy over personal familiarity.
Responds to Mrs. Deagle's accusations calmly but refuses to apologize initially, shows frustration by rolling his eyes.
Ultimately apologizes to Mrs. Deagle despite feeling wronged, indicating willingness to maintain peace and responsibility.
Calls the next customer after feeling angry and humiliated, maintains composure and continues working.
Helps Tracy with her coat and compliments her politely, showing social grace.
Shrugs and is embarrassed when confronted by Gary about not standing up to Mrs. Deagle.
Carries and reads a book on King Arthur and knights instead of engaging in risky or immature behavior.
Does not stand up to Mrs. Deagle when she receives special treatment from Roland, showing a lack of assertiveness.
Laughs quietly at a funny part in his book, showing a childlike joy.
Sits alone reading and appears immersed in fantasy, showing no signs of engaging or connecting with others around him.
Stops to help Pete after his schoolbooks scatter, checks if he's okay, helps him up, offers a ride home, and helps pick up his books.
Tries to entertain Pete with an energetic story during the car ride.
Generously gives Pete a copy of his book to borrow.
Jokes about his unfinished trilogy and promises an autographed copy when published, showing pride but also encouragement.
Greets Dorry politely and with enthusiasm, shows genuine interest in the sword, thanks Dorry sincerely after paying.
Pays Dorry for the sword with partial payment and agrees to weekly installments without complaint.
Examines the sword carefully and pays the seller responsibly with a weekly payment plan.
Shows enthusiasm and care by handling the sharp sword cautiously and wrapping it carefully under his arm.
Pets the family dog Barney upon entering the house.
Responds briefly and with a sigh when his mother calls him 'honey', showing mild irritation but no hostility.
Picks up the sword, tests different poses and swings with it, then smiles confidently.
Responds vaguely to his mother when asked about work ('Okay...') without elaboration.
Responds defensively and dismissively to Lynn's questions and concern, telling her it's none of her business.
Rejects Lynn's attempt at physical affection by moving his hand away when she calls him 'honey'.
Expresses frustration and insecurity about his future and potential failure as a writer, showing vulnerability.
Pauses and finally gives in to Lynn's request to forget their issues for the night
Walks to his father and embraces him happily
Sits silently, burning with emotion while others express joy
Initially insists on leaving to make it on his own, showing some confidence and determination.
Ultimately gives in and stays, pausing and nodding to Lynn's request.
Greets his father warmly and follows him into the living room, engaging appropriately.
Passively sits and watches events unfold without taking initiative or demonstrating control.
Forces himself to take Mogwai despite hesitation, tolerates the creature licking his cheek, forces a smile for the photo despite discomfort.
Looks nauseous and inches back from holding Mogwai initially.
Calls Mogwai 'little bastard' after being scratched, showing frustration.
Initially unsure and hesitant to hold Mogwai, inching back and forcing himself to take the creature.
Forces a smile for the picture despite discomfort, showing some social adaptability.
Reacts with frustration and calls Mogwai a 'little bastard' after being scratched, showing lack of patience and control.
Continuing to work intensely on his novel despite Mogwai's singing and distractions.
Uses bright light to control Mogwai's behavior effectively.
Responds angrily and threatens to kill Mogwai when it accidentally drops the sword.
Fails to manage Mogwai’s behavior calmly, escalating the situation with anger.
Feels sympathetic toward the frightened Mogwai, lowers his sword, comforts and pets it tenderly.
Invites Tracy for coffee and engages in friendly conversation about their dreams and interests.
Feels sympathy for the frightened Mogwai, lowers his sword and comforts the creature.
Initiates friendly conversation with Tracy and invites her for coffee before work.
Shares plans about selling his novel to quit the bank, indicating goal-setting and ambition.
Encourages Tracy not to give up on her dreams, showing support and optimism.
Warmly offers brownies to Pete when he visits, sharing food generously.
Tells Pete the Mogwai is a present from his dad, shares it tentatively.
Expresses hesitation when Pete asks to borrow Mogwai.
Shows surprise and concern when Mogwai is hurt by water.
Observes the Mogwai's reaction to water carefully, tests by splashing more water to confirm the phenomenon.
Is surprised and shocked at the Mogwai's unexpected multiplication after contact with water.
Allows Pete to take one of the creatures despite being dazed and unsure.
Expresses worry about the unknown nature of the creatures to his father.
Expresses concern and skepticism about marketing the mogwai too quickly, suggesting they should be checked out first.
Nods and accepts Gary's threat to keep hands off his girlfriend but glares at him afterward.
Questions the plan to market Mogwai without safety checks, showing skepticism and concern for prudence.
Quickly tries to leave when confronted by Gary, indicating a desire to avoid conflict rather than confront it.
After being thrown against the car by Gary, he glares at him rather than escalating, showing some restraint but limited assertiveness.
Introduces Roy Hanson to his friends, trusts him with the creatures, allows him to stay and run tests.
Squeezes water on a creature to demonstrate its reaction without apparent concern for consequences.
Wakes up and investigates strange noises in the house despite feeling nervous; takes responsibility to face unknown creatures.
Listens attentively and respectfully to Roy's detailed explanation about the creatures without dismissiveness or skepticism.
Listens attentively to Roy's explanation about the creatures and asks if there is anything else to know.
Wakes up to strange noises, notices his door ajar, and calmly takes his sword from the wall before investigating the noise downstairs.
Stares coldly at his father after the dog's death without offering comfort or support.
Looks up at the attic door where the creatures are scratching, showing concern and attention.
Nudges his father to show him what he spotted, indicating cooperation and shared responsibility.
Billy tries to move but he's frozen while the creatures eat the dog.
Billy stares coldly at his father and speaks confidently, telling him to forget it.
Billy and Rand carefully enter the attic with flashlights and Billy spots the nine pods, alerting his father.
Insists on destroying the cocoons despite scientific curiosity, motivated by anger over his dog's death.
Expresses concern and eagerness to act immediately by suggesting they should remove the cocoons themselves instead of waiting.
Displays doubt and uncertainty when reassured by his father to stop worrying.
Suggests not waiting for professionals and proposes doing the removal themselves.
Shows doubtful and uncertain expression despite the locked attic and assurances, indicating lack of confidence.
Counts out money to customers and works alongside Tracy efficiently in the shop.
Greets Mrs. Deagle with a forced smile and attempts to remain calm despite her sour attitude and harsh words.
Tries to suggest Mrs. Deagle see a bank officer in a polite manner while being verbally attacked.
Bites his lip, holding in his anger publicly in front of others.
Attempts to remain calm and professional while dealing with a difficult and rude customer (Mrs. Deagle), suggests a reasonable solution (seeing a bank officer).
Shrugs and tries to stay calm but bites his lip holding in anger when the situation escalates and Mrs. Deagle demands to speak to a superior.
Refuses to falsely apologize and instead insults Mrs. Deagle honestly despite social pressure.
Refuses to apologize insincerely and instead speaks his honest, albeit rude, feelings to Mrs. Deagle despite social pressure and authority.
Displays confidence and self-expression by standing up for himself openly in front of others, including Tracy and the bank customers.
Fails to take the situation seriously and alienates himself from authority (Roland) by insulting Mrs. Deagle, leading to his firing.
Responds quickly to Lynn's fearful call about the noises in the attic and rushes home despite hazardous weather conditions.
Smiles in response to Tracy's compliment in a friendly manner.
Responds immediately to his mother's call about the noises, leaves work quickly to help.
Attempts to drive fast in heavy snowfall and icy roads, resulting in losing control of the car and crashing off the road.
Tries to start the stalled car, shows frustration but keeps trying.
Runs home urgently through the snow, showing concern and urgency.
Calls out for his mother upon entering the dark, silent house, showing care and concern.
Calls out for his mom with concern/hears giggling, showing worry and cautiousness.
Approaches the attic despite fear, showing protective and brave behavior.
Picks up mom's valium bottle stained with blood, indicating care and attention to her safety.
Grabs the sword and prepares to defend himself and possibly others.
Quickly flips on the bright hall light upon reaching the top of the stairs to illuminate the dark attic.
Clutches a sword and confronts the creature leaping at him, raising and swinging the sword.
Appears scared, shaking, and calling out nervously for his mom.
Retrieves a potentially useful weapon (sword) before confronting the unknown threat.
Steps back and dashes inside after an object (Valium bottle stained with blood) is thrown at his feet, showing hesitation.
Hits and kills attacking creature mid-air with sword, demonstrates accuracy and quick reflexes.
Has a moment of emotional distress when he sees Lynn's dead body but regains composure to continue fighting.
Moves cautiously and prepares for attack when walking downstairs, showing situational awareness.
Defends himself against surprise attack from creature leaping on his back, effectively kills it after repeated strikes.
Successfully dodges thrown plates and counters with precise sword strikes, demonstrating agility and focus under pressure.
Fights fiercely to protect himself and others from attacking Mogwai, showing courage and decisiveness.
Kills the creatures by stabbing and burning them without hesitation despite his own injury.
Wrestles the creature to protect himself and tries to stop it from escaping.
Follows Mogwai's footprints outside in harsh weather to track the creature.
Wrestles with the creature despite being attacked, manages to grab the sword and wound the creature, attempts to finish it off.
Allows the creature to escape through the window despite having it wounded and nearly defeated.
Quickly notices and follows the creature's footprints in the snow, pursuing it despite a blizzard starting.
Rushes over to help Peggy and pulls her out of the snowman despite danger.
Quickly attacks the snowman to protect Peggy.
Rushed to Peggy's backyard on noticing danger, engaged immediately by pulling Peggy free from the snowman’s chest with a tug of war.
Attacked the snowman repeatedly with his sword until the threat was destroyed.
Noticed the footprints Mogwai left and pursued the creature rather than ignoring the threat.
Chases after Mogwai through woods and follows into a closed building despite difficulties, showing persistence and concern.
Breaks the window with his sword to enter the building and retrieve the creature, showing resourcefulness and determination to protect.
Calls out to the creature despite fear, moves to investigate the sound, shows courage in a frightening situation.
Protects himself when attacked, separates from the creature, quickly recovers and assesses his injuries.
Runs and locks the door to prevent creatures from following, escapes to safety, prioritizes self-preservation in a dangerous situation.
Moves faster toward the light box despite fear, attempts to investigate the source of the sound.
Drops flashlight and sword when attacked, falls backward into the pool.
Separates himself from the creature in the water and swims out of the pool.
Runs to the exit doorway upon hearing rumbling and seeing violent water movements.
Watches from the doorway in shock as creatures emerge and multiply rapidly without immediate action.
Closes and locks the door behind him, runs to the window, and escapes by crawling out.
Confidently informs the sheriff about the dangerous creatures despite skepticism.
Shows seriousness and helplessness about the situation, demonstrating sincerity and trustworthiness.
Responds with visible upset and glare when his loss and seriousness are doubted, implying frustration but also sincerity.
Does not respond with hostility despite being mocked by authority figures, indicating tolerance and restraint.
Explains the danger of the gremlins calmly and tries to make the sheriff understand the severity of the situation.
Appears nervous and helpless when confronted by the sheriff and officer, who openly doubt his story.
Stands up and firmly asserts the truth of his claims despite skepticism, demonstrating resolve and confidence.
Insists on more help and warns others about danger despite anger from Frank and Officer Brent.
Pleading with Officer Brent not to enter alone, showing concern for his safety.
Hacks at handcuff chain desperately and breaks free despite panic; attempts to escape to warn people.
Leaves Brent behind while he is attacked by creatures, does not intervene or assist him directly.
Drives urgently to warn neighbors about a dangerous threat, knocks on doors to inform them despite skepticism.
Flips on the police siren and heads for town to warn people about the threat.
Steers the patrol car into a driveway abruptly and commands Mr. Futters to lock windows and board up, and keep lights on, showing awareness of defense measures.
Acts breathlessly and hyperactively, struggles to communicate the seriousness of the situation effectively to skeptical neighbors.
Does not successfully convince Mr. Futters and others of the danger, leading to their disbelief and mockery.
Calls Mr. Deagle's wife names and behaves erratically in the bank.
Stands defeated and frustrated in response to neighbors' hostility.
Defends himself by attacking a creature that leaps at him.
Carries a sword and swings it effectively to defend himself from a Mogwai attack, successfully knocking it down and stabbing it.
Engages in a conflict with Mr. Deagle, is called crazy and a troublemaker, appears frustrated and defeated after being threatened and ordered to leave the yard.
Attempts to rescue Mrs. Deagle by responding to her screams and trying to protect himself and call for help despite fear.
Runs to police car and shuts door to keep creatures out, prioritizing his own safety but hears and witnesses harm to others.
Panics and screams into police radio for help, showing desperation but also eagerness to save town and others.
Looks away when Mrs. Deagle is attacked and killed, indicating possible distress or helplessness yet a momentary emotional withdrawal.
Runs to the police car and locks the door, attempting to protect himself from attacking creatures.
Flips on the police radio to call for help despite overwhelming danger and panic.
Seems overwhelmed, screaming and panicking on the radio, exhibiting fear and stress under pressure.
Looks away as Mrs. Deagle is attacked, showing possible hesitation or inability to act immediately.
Panics and screams into the radio mike, urgently calls for help as creatures attack town.
Thinks fast and uses police car sirens and lights to scare away creatures, protecting others.
Drops the radio mike in panic during immediate danger.
Responds quickly to Tracy's scream for help, drives to her location, and attempts a rescue despite danger.
Protects Tracy by pulling her to safety through the window and holding her securely to prevent a fall.
Sacrifices his sword by dropping it to hold Tracy, prioritizing her safety over his own defense.
Pulls the ladder away from pursuing creatures to protect Tracy, showing quick thinking and care.
Keeps one protective arm around Tracy while preparing to fight the creatures.
Embraces Tracy after defeating the creatures, showing relief and connection.
Focuses on fighting and survival without showing aggression beyond necessary self-defense.
Holds Tracy's hand, comforting her as she is sickened by the horror outside.
Stops the car upon noticing something concerning ahead, showing attentiveness and caution.
Drives as fast as possible through the heavy snow to get out of town, showing urgency and control despite dangerous conditions.
Notices Frank's overturned police car and stops his vehicle to check or possibly help, showing situational awareness.
Holds Tracy's hand to comfort her amid terror, demonstrating emotional support but not directly related to competence in a skillful or capable sense.
Rescues Gary by opening the jammed car door and pulling him out quickly.
Gently leads scared and helpless Gary to the safety of the police car and encourages him to stay in the light.
Informs Gary clearly and honestly that his brother is dead.
Sits silently and stares ahead after others comfort each other, showing internal struggle or distance.
Invites Gary and Tracy inside to warm up and reassures them the creature has not arrived yet.
Explains the danger and tries to organize help to control the threat, showing concern for others' safety.
Defends himself calmly against accusations and maintains truthfulness despite anger from others.
Lunges angrily at Gary when accused of being a murderer, showing a loss of control.
Explains the origin and behavior of the gremlins clearly to others, showing good understanding and ability to anticipate their movements.
Attempts to get help and keep the gremlins under control despite others dismissing his warnings.
Reacts angrily and emotionally when accused by Gary, leading to a physical lunge at him.
Despite being bruised and bloodied, continues to lead and inform others about the gremlin threat.
Fails to communicate effectively beforehand to prevent tragedy, as accused by Gary and the townspeople.
Turns away and cools off after being told they must stick together.
Expresses desire to contact his dad and stay safe with the group.
Asks Dorry for a safe place without windows to protect the group.
Clutches his sword and urges the group to hurry and get to safety.
Organizes the group to stay in the storage room until daybreak, taking initiative to protect others.
Suggests contacting the authorities and trying to reach his dad.
Asks Dorry for a safe, windowless place to stay.
Clutches his sword and urges everyone to hurry to safety.
Turns away and cools off after the fight breaks up instead of trying to deescalate.
Thinks fast and acts quickly to block the door to keep everyone safe.
Thinking fast, moves to a large cabinet and slides it in front of the door to block creatures' entry, instructing Gary to help.
Sits back and states they are safe after barricading the door, despite ongoing noises outside.
Volunteers to watch the door and protect the group during a difficult night.
Shows vulnerability by crying alone after a traumatic event.
Nods to let Tracy sleep near him, providing her comfort and a sense of safety.
Volunteers to watch the door and protect the group overnight, showing a sense of responsibility and vigilance.
He initially holds a sword on his lap while guarding, demonstrating readiness and alertness.
Billy breaks down emotionally and cries alone, showing vulnerability in a crisis.
Falls asleep while on guard, letting the sword drop and his hand quiver, indicating a lapse in vigilance and control.
Comforts others by saying 'Everything's okay...I just dropped my sword' when they look scared.
Takes initiative to open the jammed door and checks surroundings despite danger and damaged environment.
Suggests to try the phone to get help after assessing the situation, showing concern for group safety.
Insists that the group stay together and fight the creatures rather than risk one member going alone at night.
Plans to get something to eat for the group before continuing to work together.
Focuses on fighting the creatures and getting the advantage while it's daylight, prioritizing group's safety.
Insists on sticking together and fighting the creatures instead of splitting up and risking danger alone.
Plans to get food and then go to work, showing practical steps in a crisis situation.
Focuses on attacking creatures during daylight when they have the advantage, demonstrating tactical thinking.
Leads the group in strategizing about where the creatures are hiding and considers others' suggestions.
Invites Gary to come in with him, acknowledging Gary's knowledge of the theater.
Decides to blow up the theater to destroy the creatures, showing willingness to take responsibility for a dangerous action.
Encourages everyone to stick together and keep close to the flashlight for safety.
Listens to others’ ideas and allows Tracy to try distracting the creatures with the projector.
Takes charge by organizing the group and instructs them to stick together and use the flashlight since the creatures are afraid of light.
Shows situational awareness by carefully observing the theater entrance and assessing the number of creatures inside.
Admits the difficulty of the situation openly (too many creatures, risk of being seen), indicating realistic assessment rather than reckless behavior.
Seeks input by asking others how to access the boiler room, showing collaborative problem solving.
Relies on Tracy's idea to turn on the projector to distract creatures, effectively using available resources.
Carefully leads others to safety through the theater, showing cautiousness and consideration.
Turns off the gas line to prevent danger to others, taking responsibility for the group's safety.
Asks for and uses Gary's T-shirt to create a makeshift tool, showing cooperation and resourcefulness.
Directs everyone to leave quickly after igniting the gas line, expressing concern for others' well-being.
Stops Gary from shooting recklessly and instructs to use the light instead
Picks up a sword and fights creatures to protect Dorry
Screams at Gary to get back and help, expresses need for support
Carries Dorry's body, showing responsibility and care
Confronts danger to ensure safety of others and escape
Carries Dorry's dead body out of the burning theater, showing care for fallen comrade.
Confronts Gary for leaving them behind and fights him, expressing feelings of betrayal and loyalty to friends.
Grabs Tracy's hand and runs to safety, protecting her.
Stops Tracy from killing the wounded creature, seeing it as bait to protect others.
Quickly picks up the sword after Gary's death to defend himself and Tracy, then escapes to the police car and locks the doors.
Recognizes that the creature on the back seat is calling for help and logically deduces that as long as it lives, more creatures will follow them.
Formulates a plan to use the wounded creature as bait to lead the creatures away from a strategic location (water tower), showing tactical thinking.
Stops Tracy from killing the creature impulsively and advises caution, showing control and thoughtful decision-making.
Shows concern and urgency to protect Mogwai and Tracy from approaching creatures.
Uses mild crude language referring to Mogwai to Tracy ('little bastard').
Collaborates cooperatively with Tracy, instructing her to find something for Mogwai's safety.
Forces wounded Mogwai into toolbox to contain it despite it biting and scratching him.
Carries the tool box with trapped Mogwai crying inside while fleeing danger, takes responsibility to contain the creature.
Looks into the distance, assesses situation calmly, prioritizes safety.
Grabs Tracy's hand and urges her to come on despite danger, showing protective behavior.
Successfully traps the Mogwai in a locked toolbox despite being bitten and scratched.
Checks the car engine and identifies that the coil wires have been ripped out, realizing the car won't run.
Decides there is no time to fix the car and instead chooses to flee immediately with Tracy, carrying the toolbox and leading her to the greenhouse.
Takes Tracy's hand and climbs the tree together to escape danger.
Protects Tracy by fighting off attacking creatures to keep her safe despite being outnumbered.
Stands up and knocks creatures off unconscious Tracy when she is attacked.
Continues to fight to defend Tracy and himself despite wounds and pain.
Takes Tracy's hand and climbs the tree, attempts to hold the creatures at bay with a sword.
Attempts to fight off multiple attacking creatures despite being outnumbered.
Fails to escape or defeat the creatures as they gnaw the tree trunk and eventually bring the tree down.
After falling, stands up and knocks creatures off Tracy, tries to fight further despite injuries.
Is overwhelmed by the numerous creatures, drops his sword, cries out, and eventually gives up.
Kneels, resting Tracy's head and shoulders in his lap, kisses her lightly on the lips, holds her tight, helps her to her feet.
Watches the creatures die in horror, showing empathy for the suffering beings despite their threat.
Collapses in the snow, exhausted, allowing Tracy to kneel beside him, showing vulnerability and trust.
Throws his sword into the snow after battle, symbolizing release of aggression.
Watches the creatures suffer and melt in sunlight, showing awareness of the situation.
Kneels and comforts Tracy, showing care and emotional support during crisis, demonstrating calm and presence of mind.
Picks up his sword and exits the greenhouse confidently, prepared for any remaining threats.
Throws his sword firmly into the snow before collapsing from exhaustion, symbolizing completion of his task and acceptance of his limits.
Collapses unconscious shortly after the conflict is resolved, indicating physical exhaustion but no signs of panic or incompetence prior.
Holds his father tightly, shows concern for Tracy, indicating care and emotional connection.
In panic, insists he did not open the toolbox and fights against medical staff, showing stress but also sincerity and distress about consequences.
Despite being injured and shocked, tries to communicate important information about the locked toolbox and denies opening it, showing awareness and concern.
Jumps out of bed and tears out his I.V. despite medical advice, acting impulsively and risking further injury.
